title: Best and Worst Case Scenarios for Bonds
text:
Woke up from a catnap this afternoon and CNBC had a blip on Jamie Dimon's thoughts about the possibility of the U.S. going into negative interest rates, and he didn't seem to think that would happen here. I was still a little groggy (I'm not usually a napper) so I might have missed some of the details, but from what I gathered, he thought that interest rates was more of a country-specific issue, and that just because some government issues have gone negative, it didn't necessarily follow that we would.

I've never been any better than the next person in figuring where interest rates will go, and I'm one of many who never thought we would see negative interest rates anywhere. For now, I will continue to put some money into my online savings (both accounts still holding at 2.40%), my Frost Total Return Bond (FIJEX) and PONAX (no introduction needed). I know that PONAX has had an issue and the NAV has dropped, but I'm going to look at it as a buying opportunity (have some money on the way to my Schwab account right now for that). I'm going to let the active bond fund managers manage, just on the off chance that they know more about bonds than I do...
